citation.article-title: Isolation of Desulfovibrio intestinalis sp. nov. from the hindgut of the lower termite Mastotermes darwiniensis.

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio intestinalis sp. nov.
Desulfovibrio intestinalis (in.tes.ti·na.lis; M.L. adj. intestinalis, the isolate KMS2 lives in the intestine of termites)
Cells are curved rods, 1-1.4 μm x 0.4-0.5 μm, and monotrichous polar flagellated.
Gram-negative.
Desulfoviridin is present.
Anaerobic growth.
Optimal growth at 37°C with a doubling time of 12.5 h.
Various substrates are oxidized in the presence of sulfate.
Pyruvate and lactate are also fermented (Table 1).
Aerobic respiration with different substrates (Table 2).
Electron acceptors are sulfate, thiosulfate, and sulfite.
Catalase positive.
The G+C content of the DNA is 54.5-55.5 mol%.
Strain KMS2 was isolated from the hindgut of the lower termite Mastotermes darwiniensis Froggatt.
Type strain is KMS2 (DSM 11275).
Characteristics as shown in Tables 1-3.

In contrast to Desuifovibrio desulfuricans (strain Essex 6, type strain) and Desulfovibrio desulfuricans (ATCC 27774), strain KMS2 is unable to use nitrate as electron acceptor and choline (only determined for strain Essex 6), glycerophosphate, glycerol, 1,2-propandiol, and n-propanol as substrates, nor does it ferment fumarate (Devereux et al. 1990; Rebum and Patel 1994).
In contrast with Desulfovibrio desulfuricans, strain KMS2 can use alanine as substrate.
The accession number of its 16S rDNA sequence is Y12254 (EMBL).
Its 16S rDNA sequence showed the highest similarity (95.9%) to Desulfovibrio desulfuricans ATCC 27774.
The DNA-DNA homology of strain KMS2 with Desulfovibrio desulfuricans Essex 6 (DSM 642, type strain) is 44.6%.
